Apparel retailers stepped out in style Friday as several handed out good earnings reports that sent their stocks higher and made the industry group one of the best performers of the day. The 44-stock Retail-Apparel/Shoes/Accessories industry group ranks No. 23 out of the 197 groups in Friday's IBD. It's gained nearly 6% in the last three months. Ross Stores (ROST)…

Chico's FAS (CHS) reported fourth-quarter results that topped expectations and announced that it is closing stores and eliminating jobs to cut costs.The women's clothing retailer said Thursday it had laid off 12% of its headquarters and field management employee base, cutting 240 existing positions. Those cuts are expected to result in $38 million of annualized savings.Shares rose 1.5% to 17.62 in the stock market today. It is trading about 8% below a 19.08 buy point from a cup-with-handle base.On Wednesday, shares dropped 4% in reaction to a Wall Street Journal report that private-equity firm Sycamore Partners had abandoned its takeover attempt of Chico's because it failed to line up financing.Chico's said it is accelerating its store closures and plans to shut down 120 stores over the next three years, which will result in expense savings of $55.2 million.The company, which operates the brands Chico's, White House Black Market, Soma Intimates and Boston Proper, had 1,547 store locations as of Jan. 31.For fiscal 2015, Chico's plans to open 40 new stores, significantly less than the 109 locations opened last year, and close 35 stores.Chico's earned 5 cents a share in Q4, up from 4 cents the prior year. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters were expecting earnings of 2 cents a share.Revenue increased 7.6% to $657 million, above projections for $640 million.Comparable store sales in the quarter increased 4.3% following a 3.4% decrease in the prior year, which Chico's says reflects an increase in transaction count and average dollar sale.Chico's did not provide earnings or revenue guidance for fiscal 2015, but said it expects comparable store sales to increase a low single digit.During the year, the company projects capital expenditures of $100 million, with $30 million for the rollout of its new point-of-sale system, which includes mobile technology.Chico's says it plans to repurchase $250 million in shares in Q1, financed through a combination of cash and debt.The Retail-Apparel/Shoes/Accessories group is ranked No. 23 out of the 197 industry groups IBD tracks, led by Lululemon (LULU) and Ross Stores (ROST) .Follow Alissa Williams on Twitter: @IBD_AWilliams.RELATED:Chico's Stock Drops As Sycamore Buyout Hopes Fizzle.
Stocks opened the final session of what has been a strong month on a weak note, and under a hail of middling economic news.
The Nasdaq, the Dow Jones industrial average and the S&P 500 slipped 0.1% apiece.
Volume was quietly mixed, up 1% on the NYSE and down 2% on the Nasdaq compared with trade at the same time Thursday.
The stock market today received little help from the economic calendar.

The Commerce Department before the start of trade released its revised fourth-quarter GDP estimate of 2.2%. The figure was slightly better than the 2.1% revision expected by analysts, but still well below the department's initial estimate of 2.6% growth. And it was less than half of Q3's 5% GDP growth pace.

The Chicago-region purchasing managers index for February was also weak. The manufacturing gauge from Kingsbury International came in at 45.8, far below January's 59.4 reading and disappointing expectations for a mild slowdown to 58.7.

The University of Michigan offered up better news. Its final Consumer Sentiment Index reading for February was 95.4, up from its initial estimate of 93.6 and better than the 94 tally expected by economists.
Pending home sales rose 1.7% in January, the Association of Realtors said. That easily beat December's 3.7% decline. Economists' consensus projections were for a 2% increase.
There was no shortage of positive stock news, however.

Monster Beverage (MNST) kicked out a 12% gain, spiking to a new high in — you know it — monster trade. The Corona, Calif.-based drink maker's fourth-quarter earnings and revenue were well above consensus forecasts, despite a heavy load of legal expenses. The company said it expects to close Coca-Cola's (KO) $2.15 billion purchase of a 16.5% interest in Monster in the second half of the year. The gain left the stock thoroughly extended after a rebound from 10-week support.

Discount retailer Ross Stores (ROST) also stabbed out a new high, jumping 5% in fast trade. The Dublin, Calif.-based chain said Q4 earnings and revenue comfortably beat forecasts. Management offered Q1 and full-year guidance below consensus forecasts, but announced a $1.6 billion, two-year share buyback initiative. The gain left shares extended above a 97.88 flat base buy point.

Autodesk (ADSK) popped 5% in early action. The developer of design software reported better-than-forecast, fourth-quarter sales and earnings, but offered mixed Q1 and full-year guidance. The gain lifted shares to a new high, not quite 2% above a 63.10 cup-base buy point.Stocks opened the final session of what has been a strong month on a weak note, and under a hail of middling economic news.The Nasdaq, the Dow Jones industrial average and the S&P 500 slipped 0.1% apiece.Volume was quietly mixed, up 1% on the NYSE and down 2% on the Nasdaq compared with trade at the same time Thursday.The stock market today received little help from the economic calendar.The Commerce Department before the start of trade released its revised fourth-quarter GDP estimate of 2.2%. Shares of Chico's FAS (CHS) retretaed Wednesday on reports that Sycamore Partners has abandoned its takeover attempt of the women's clothing retailer.
The private-equity firm reportedly failed to line up financing for the deal on acceptable terms, the Wall Street Journal first said late Tuesday.

Chico's shares gapped down 3.4% to 17.50 in afternoon trading on the stock market today. The stock had been working on a long cup-with-handle base, but the drop appears to have unraveled that effort. However, the stock rebounded from an early low of 16.90, finding support just above its 50-day moving average

Chico's, the parent of brands including White House Black Market and Soma, has a so-so IBD Composite Rating of 66. In other words, its shares outperform 66% of all stocks on the market as measured by fundamental and technical factors such as earnings and sales growth, return on equity and relative price performance.
Sycamore, which owns fashion brands including Talbots and Hot Topic, ended buyout talks with Express (EXPR) last month, also due to the inability to find acceptable financing.
The Retail-Apparel/Shoes/Accessories group is ranked No. 20 out of the 197 industry groups IBD tracks, led by Ross Stores (ROST) and Lululemon (LULU).

Did consumers go in for basketball shoes, sneakers, sports gear and athletic apparel gear over the holidays?

Investors will find out when giant athletic footwear and apparel retail operator Foot Locker (FL) and sporting goods retailer Dick's Sporting Goods (DKS) report fourth-quarter financial results in coming days.
Foot Locker is rated highly by IBD and has logged at least double-digit profit growth in all but one of the past 16 quarters.

If analysts are on the money, Foot Locker is on track to keep up its streak when it reports fourth-quarter results before the stock market opens on Friday, March 6. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expect Foot Locker's fourth-quarter earnings to come in up 11% at 91 cents a share. While that would still be a healthy gain, it would be a slower pace than the 22% gain it saw in the third quarter.
They see sales rising 4.70% to $1.875 billion. That would be less of an increase than the 7% rise it saw in the third quarter.

If analysts are on target, Dick's will see fourth-quarter earnings rise 10% to $1.22 a share, when it reports results for the quarter before the stock market opens on Tuesday, March 3. That would be slightly faster than the 9% increase it saw in the prior quarter.
Dick's is expected to post an 8.8% rise in sales to $2.118 billion. That would be a quicker pace than the 2% increase it saw in the prior quarter.

Foot Locker is part of IBD's Retail/Apparel/Shoes/Accessories industry group, which also includes Ross Stores (ROST) and Lululemon Athletica (LULU) . Foot Locker has a 93 Composite Rating from IBD out of a possible 99, and is seen by analysts as one of the most important vendors of athletic shoes from Nike (NKE), which has a 90 Composite Rating.

Dick's is a part of IBD's Retail-Leisure Products industry group. Stocks struggled Friday, sliding in sawtooth fashion to end with significant losses. The Nasdaq, IBD 50 and S&P 500 suffered dents of 0.5%, 0.4% and 0.3%, respectively. Volume rose across the board. The action was sufficiently negative to slap a distribution day on the Nasdaq and the S&P 500. It was the first such day for either index in three…

The major indexes fell again Wednesday as the S&P 500 logged its fifth loss in six sessions. Yet market conditions for growth-stock pickers remain positive. The S&P 500 slipped 0.4% as volume on the New York Stock Exchange crept higher. Disappointing private sector jobs growth from ADP may have disappointed traders. The Nasdaq composite eased 0.3%, less than Tuesday's 0.6%…

Earnings reports sparked some of Friday's new highs, including a few in the rising consumer sector. Ross Stores (ROST) gapped up after the discount apparel retailer beat expectations with its fourth-quarter results, reported late Thursday. Same-store sales jumped 6% for the quarter, topping the company's forecast. Ross also cited improved operating margins. The stock jumped 6.76, or 7%, to 105.81…

Business was picking up at a steady clip at the Foot Locker store in Times Square on the frigid cold morning of Feb. 23. Customers were lined up at the cash register, carrying boxes of men's basketball shoes, brightly-colored women's running shoes and sneakers for everyday wear, to name a few. NBA basketball fever was apparent throughout the Foot Locker[ticker…

Several stocks cleared buy points en route to new highs Thursday as the market rebounded sharply. Citrix Systems (CTXS) soared 8.66, or 12%, to 80.58 in very heavy trading after the software developer reported that its Q3 profit jumped 39% to $1.04 a share, the biggest increase in more than four years and well ahead of Wall Street estimates. Sales…
Major averages continued a recent theme Thursday, trading mixed and mostly unchanged about two hours into the session.
The Nasdaq perked up to a 0.3% gain, while the Dow Jones industrial average and S&P 500 were mostly unchanged. Nasdaq volume was tracking about 15% higher than Wednesday's level. NYSE volume rose 1%.

In economic news, a higher than expected reading on jobless claims data was somewhat offset by a better-than-expected jump in January durable goods orders. Soft energy prices led to a sharp drop in prices paid by consumers in January. The second estimate of Q4 GDP will be out tomorrow at 8:30 a.m. ET.

In the stock market today, IBD 50 names Akorn (AKRX) and Avago Technologies (AVGO) soared on strong earnings. Akorn jumped 12% after reporting a 257% surge in quarterly profit and a 168% jump in sales. Chip designer Avago soared 14% on impressive fiscal Q1 results.

Wall Street also cheered earnings from Salesforce.com (CRM). Shares rose 11%. It gapped up over a conventional entry at 64.84, but there's plenty of precedent showing that buying near a stock's open price on the day it gaps up is sound strategy. Salesforce.com's open price was 70.02.
Medivation (MDVN) and Epam Systems (EPAM) were other earnings winners that shot higher in big volume.

Meanwhile, IBD Leaderboard name LinkedIn (LNKD) scored an all-time high, rising 2%. Dow Jones Newswires reported that Morgan Stanley initiated coverage with an overweight rating and set a 310 price target.

Ross Stores (ROST) was holding just above a 97.88 buy point ahead of its earnings report after the close. Joe Fath took the driver's seat of $42.8 billion T. Rowe Price Growth Stock Fund a little more than a year ago, on Jan. 16, 2014. Recently, thismutual fund has shifted into higher gear. The fund is up 9.16% since Fath took charge vs. 9.20% for his large-cap growth rivals tracked by Morningstar Inc. and 12.28% for the S&P 500 in the stock market today.
In the past three months he's up 2.33% vs. 1.75% for his peer group and 1.24% for the big-cap bogey.
Fath says it took about six months to reposition the portfolio to his liking. Performance since then reflects that shift in stock investment ideas.
The portfolio holds 100 names, down from 118 when he took over. His top 10 account for 26% of his money, down from 33%. The tail end of the portfolio takes up 10% of his money, down from 21%.
His aim is for all-weather growth companies, which can expand earnings no matter what's happening in the macro environment surrounding them.
That's how he sees LinkedIn (LNKD). "Its core recruiting business is maturing but continues to do well," he said.
In addition, Fath likes new opportunities that LinkedIn is nurturing. One is Bizo, an acquisition that aims to help advertisers reach businesses and professionals.
Another is its new version of Sales Navigator, which is a sales-lead facilitator tool. "That should provide a nice tailwind in the back half of the year," he said.
Those improvements should help LinkedIn boost revenue, making its current expensive valuation look more reasonable, Fath says.
Head In The Cloud

Fath also likes ServiceNow (NOW) . Its core business is its information technology service management (ITSM) software, which it delivers as a cloud service. Its platform lets clients create customized applications. Fath sees the firm's CreateNow Development Suite, a set of tools to manage the lifecycle of an app, as a promising revenue source.
Also, ServiceNow is finding new users in human resources, operations maintenance and facilities departments, beyond its core IT clients, he says.
Fath began his stake in Vipshop (VIPS) in last year's second quarter. He has increased his stake each quarter since then.
Fath sees Vipshop as a unique retailer in China. It is a discounter along the lines of Ross Stores (ROST) and TJX's (TJX) Marshalls and T.J. Maxx in the U.S.
"But its sales are entirely online. And there is no Marshalls or T.J. Maxx or Ross Stores, either online or bricks and mortar, in China," he said.
Adding To Celgene
Fath's fund has boosted its weighting in Celgene (CELG) for at least three quarters in a row. He likes how the company has expanded beyond heavy reliance on its cancer drug Revlimid.
In November, Celgene got European approval for its first immunology drug, Otezla, to treat psoriasis and psoriatic arthritis.
It's also ramping up for sales from other cancer drugs Pomalyst and Abraxane.

The company's GD-301 drug for treatment of Crohn's disease shows promise as a game-changer, Fath says. He also likes Celgene's investments in smaller biotechs.Joe Fath took the driver's seat of $42.8 billion T. Rowe Price Growth Stock Fund a little more than a year ago, on Jan. 16, 2014. Investors seeking steadily rising dividends should pay attention to stocks in the S&P Dividend Aristocrats and S&P High Yield Dividend Aristocrats indexes. Why? Companies that make those lists have consistently raised their payout each year for at least the past two decades. If a company's dividend-hike streak ends, Standard & Poor's gives it the boot. Next week, the S&P High…

The Big Cap 20 is showing itself to be a good representation of today's market leadership, as technology, health care and consumer stocks dominate the list.A glance of the IBD Smart NYSE + Nasdaq Tables shows chips, medical, apparel, retail and other technology sectors make up most of the top 10 sectors. That's a fitting reflection of what you find in the Big Cap 20. Most of the 20 stocks can be categorized in one of those areas.In technology, a couple of chipmakers rank among the leading big caps, along with some business-service tech companies.Analog Devices (ADI) is one of the more interesting charts. The stock broke out of a cup-shaped base on Feb. 17 and has risen 3% from that entry.The chipmaker earned 63 cents a share excluding items for the January-ended quarter, beating expectations. Sales rose 23%, as the top line continued an accelerating trend of growth.Analysts noted strength in its industrial and automotive markets.Apple (AAPL), a tech leader that could be viewed as a consumer stock too, is another high-tech stock that's found a home in the Big Cap 20. The stock is near new highs, extended from its breakout past 119.85 last month.In the medical sector, drugmakers Biogen Idec (BIIB), Pharmacyclics (PCYC) and Valeant Pharmaceuticals (VRX) have rallied in recent weeks and account for some of the best percentage gains in the Big Cap 20 over the past couple of weeks.UnitedHealth Group (UNH) and Cigna (CI) are part of a broad rally in HMO stocks.While those medical leaders are extended, Mylan (MYL) is setting up in a base with a 59.70 buy point.However, its shares fell moderately after the close Monday, when the company reported Q4 earnings of $1.05 a share, an increase of 35%. Sales rose 18% to $2.08 billion.Mylan forecast 2015 revenues of $9.6 billion to $10.1 billion.In consumer stocks, the big cap leaders run the gamut of auto-parts chain O'Reilly Automotive (ORLY), Starbucks (SBUX) and discount retailer Ross Stores (ROST).Ross Stores shined Friday as its earnings report sent shares gapping up to a 7% gain and a record high.For the first two months of 2015, the Big Cap 20 has acquitted itself quite satisfactorily. It rose 6.9%, far better than the 2.2% gain for the S&P 500, which is a broad gauge of big-capitalization stocks.Qorvo (QRVO) may be an unfamiliar name on a list filled with familiar brands. The company is the name adopted when RF Micro Devices and TriQuint merged to create a leading manufacturer of cellular radio frequency technology used for wireless communications, military and other applications.The stock is consolidating, while finding support at the 10-week moving average.

Stocks struggled for direction, ending narrowly mixed Wednesday amid better-than-expected new-home sales and a second day of testimony from Fed chief Janet Yellen. But some stocks made waves after hours.

Salesforce.com (CRM) bolted 11% in extended trading after posting Q4 2015 results that met views. Earnings came in at 14 cents a share, double from a year ago. Sales rose 26% to more than $1.44 billion.
Avago Technologies (AVGO) rallied 4% after it delivered fiscal Q1 results above views. The chip designer also announced it was buying Emulex (ELX), which was soaring after hours.
MercadoLibre (MELI) was also up about 4% in extended trading, despite posting mixed quarterly results.

In the regular session, the Nasdaq eased a fraction, ending a 10-day run. The S&P; 500 slipped 0.1%. But the Dow Jones industrial average rose 0.1%. According to preliminary data, volume end higher on both major exchanges in the stock market today.

Aruba Networks (ARUN) soared 21% on reports that it's in talks to be bought by Hewlett-Packard (HPQ), which reported quarterly results late Tuesday. The late surge sent Aruba above a 22.34 buy point from a consolidation intraday.

Leaderboard name GrubHub (GRUB) rallied nearly 4% in strong volume. It cleared a cup-with-handle buy point of 41.85. Earlier this month, the provider of online food ordering services beat views with a Q4 earnings that surged 550% and sales that jumped 50%.
3D Systems (DDD), Air Lease (AL), Iconix Brand Group (ICON), Kohl's (KSS), Ross Stores (ROST) and Splunk (SPLK) are some leading stocks reporting earnings Thursday.

Weekly jobless claims, consumer prices and durable goods will be out Thursday morning. "Markedly" strengthened holiday sales at Express (EXPR) led the clothing retailer to revise higher its fourth-quarter and full-year earnings guidance. Express, which sells men's and women's clothing and accessories, now sees Q4 EPS in the range of 43 cents to 46 cents, a decline of 19.3% to 24.6% from last year. The company previously expected EPS of 38 cents to…

Apparel retailers have climbed quickly through IBD's industry ranks in recent weeks amid a pickup in economic growth and rising consumer confidence. The 46-stock Retail-Apparel/Shoes & Accessories group is up 16% since mid-October. That helps to explain why it has gained 36 places in the past six weeks, to No. 12 on Friday out of the 197 groups tracked by…

Institutional selling is leaving its mark in the market averages and leading stocks. Gains from a rally confirmed in October have diminished for many leaders and a defensive investing posture is warranted. A number of IBD 50 names closed below their 10-week moving averages decisively for the first time Friday. Volume was generally below average, but that can be deceptive…

Retail stocks have been strong, and three retailers made the Big Cap 20 list this week. Each of them has a defensive flavor. TJX (TJX) operates 1,113 T.J. Maxx, 485 HomeGoods and 973 Marshalls stores, all off-price retailers of apparel and home fashions. In 2012, TJX acquired Sierra Trading Post, an off-price Internet retailer based in Cheyenne, Wyo. The company…

Retailers in general posted decent sales gains in January, fueled by an improved economy, a brighter jobs picture and lower gas prices, even as shoppers took a bit of a breather from the holiday buying frenzy. But low gas prices are implicated in a major miss by warehouse club giant Costco Wholesale (COST) that ended up weighing down the industry's…
Drugmakers have dominated the Big Cap 20 list for months, but some retailers have been sneaking their way up the list of big companies the healthy earnings gains.

O'Reilly Automotive (ORLY) has been a growth story for several years. Motorists are keeping their cars longer, helping the market for aftermarket parts. As of Sept. 30, O'Reilly operated 4,311 stores in 43 states.

O'Reilly has proved to be a stock an investor can sleep with. In the last 18 quarters, the company has failed to deliver year-over-year earnings growth of 20% or more only twice, and those quarters were 19% and 18%. In the most recent quarter, EPS grew 22%. Analysts are forecasting a 19% increase in the next report. Sales increases are typically in the high single-digits.
The five-year annualized EPS growth rate is 27%. Analysts expect 20% EPS growth this year and 14% next.
The Earnings Stability Factor is 3 on a 0 to 99 scale where low numbers correspond to steady earnings growth.
The stock gapped out of a flat base Oct. 23 following the most recent earnings report and is now extended roughly 20% in the profit-taking zone.

Paint maker Sherwin-Williams (SHW) is riding an upswing in homebuying and remodeling. It's also a perennial grower now trading near an all-time high, extended after finding support at its 50-day moving average.
After earnings declines in the depressed years of 2008 and 2009, the company is back on the growth track with a five-year annualized EPS growth rate of 18%. The Earnings Stability Factor is 4.

Quarterly earnings growth has accelerated from 3% to 14%, 18% and 25% in the most recent quarter. Acceleration like that is a rare find in a stock and should be taken as an important positive development. Analysts expect 20% in the next report.
It was No. 16 on last week's Big Cap 20 list, but has fallen off this week.

Discounters have been doing well in this recovery, so it's no surprise Ross Stores (ROST) is on the Big Cap 20 list. It operates 1,146 Ross Dress for Less stores in 33 states offering name brand and designer apparel, footwear, accessories and home fashions. It also has 130 dd's Discounts stores in 10 states.
Ross also has accelerating earnings growth as EPS has gone from a 5% decline to 7%, 14% and 16% growth. Analysts are forecasting 9% growth in the next report.
The five-year annualized EPS growth rate is 21% The 2013 return on equity is 44%, well above the 17% benchmark investors should seek.
Ross is extended from a cup-with-handle base and near a 20% profit, often a good spot to take profits.

Holiday hiring is in full swing, and this year — like last year — the biggest employment gains are expected in a handful of retail sectors, according to the Pew Research Center.In November, clothing companies and department stores accounted for more than half of retail job gains, adding 121,600 and 114,700 jobs, respectively, noted Pew Research in a report issued Friday.Last year, nearly a third of the retail-job surge over the holidays occurred in clothing/accessories stores, with 202,400 jobs added from October through December. Department stores followed with 177,400 new jobs.Retail payrolls typically rise 3% to 4% between October and December, Pew said. Some 626,200 retail jobs were added in November and December last year, for a 4.1% gain over the earlier year.Other big holiday hirers are general merchandise stores and sporting goods, hobby, book and music stores, Pew said.Macy's (M) announced in late September that this year it would hire seasonal associates for about 86,000 positions at its Macy's and Bloomingdale's stores and in other parts of the company, up about 3.6% from 2013, with 10,000 of the jobs based in fulfillment centers that support online ordering and other aspects of Macy's "omnichannel" selling strategy.This holiday shopping season is broadly shaping up stronger than expected so far in terms of retailer revenue, despite some reports of a lackluster Black Friday. Sales at stores open at least a year rose 5% year over year in November, according to a Retail Metrics index, while forecasts had called for just a 3.4% rise.Considering factors such as earnings growth and stock market gains, Ross Stores (ROST) and TJX (TJX) are the highest-rated stocks in IBD's retail-apparel group, which is ranked 34 out of 197 industry groups in stock market performance. Nordstrom (JWN) and Macy's are the highest-rated stocks in the retail-department store industry, though the sector itself is ranked relatively low.What happens after all that holiday hiring? What goes up must come down. Retail payrolls typically fall 5% to 6% between December and February, Pew's research noted. Last year, the retail sector shed 888,000 jobs in the two months after December. That was more than the number hired over the holidays, as some retailers with disappointing results laid off staff or closed poorly performing stores."If history is any guide, retail payrolls will rise again this month before dropping sharply after the New Year," wrote Pew Research's Drew DeSilver.Sectors that don't much change their hiring policy over the holidays are nonseasonal grocery and drug stores and building materials and garden supply stores, which hit their peak payrolls in summer.Related: Costco, Gap Lead Solid November Holiday Start.

Though "disappointing" Q3 results prompted Goldman Sachs to cut its overall coverage view of broadline retailers to neutral from attractive, potential "disruptor" TJX (TJX) eluded the critique, instead nabbing an upgrade to buy from neutral and a spot on the firm's conviction list.

The T.J. Maxx and Marshalls parent company's global off-price model "positions it well as a disruptor and compounder with a double-digit EPS growth algorithm for the next decade consisting of (low-single-digit to mid-single-digit) comp growth, (mid-single-digit) square footage growth, operating margin expansion, and share buyback," said Goldman analyst Stephen Grambling in a note.
TJX shares rose 0.7% to 65.70 in the stock market today.

Goldman Sachs said it had expected the combination of better retail inventory management and macro factors such as lower unemployment and higher consumer confidence to support a cyclical broadlines recovery, but "while overall retail sales have accelerated, fundamentals for Broadlines in particular have not due to a combination of structural and cyclical issues that are likely to persist," according to Grambling.
Some of those issues include e-commerce share gains and share of wallet shift, as well as seasonal weather.

Grambling downgraded J.C. Penney (JCP) to sell on weaknesses in comps, e-commerce and core trends, and cut Burlington Stores (BURL) to neutral from buy. Ross Stores (ROST) was booted from Goldman Sach's conviction list, though Grambling retained a buy rating on the bargain retailer.

Some stocks rose to new highs Tuesday, but many pulled back with the broader market and energy once again led the new-lows list. CVS Health (CVS) rose 2.44, or 3%, to a new high of 92.31 in double its usual trade. The stock is now extended 16% past a 79.53 flat-base buy point it cleared in August. The drugstore operator…

Shares of TJX are sliding as the parent company of off-price retailers T.J. Maxx and Marshalls lowered its full-year earnings guidance and fell short of third-quarter revenue expectations. TJX (TJX) earnings grew 5.5% to $7.37 billion in Q3, missing views for $7.44 billion, while earnings rose 13.3% to 85 cents a share, in line with analyst forecasts. The retailer's shares…
Distribution and stalling days have been making their presence felt in the major averages in recent weeks, sparking a recent shift in outlook to "uptrend under pressure."
Despite gains for the market Thursday, sellers were around again as a 1.6% intraday gain for the Nasdaq faded to 0.5% by the close.
Still, this week's screen of leading stocks throughout IBD's 197 industry groups is home to plenty of actionable charts as well as stocks showing constructive price action post-breakout.
Among media stocks, Time Warner (TWX) is working on a cup-with-handle base with a buy point of 85.54.

In the enterprise software space, NetSuite's (N) cup-with-handle base shows a buy point of 111.08, but also a 42% correction on the left side. That's on the steep side and makes the base slightly flawed, but volume has dried up in its handle area, which is a positive.

In the tech service group, a midcap and small-cap name could try for breakouts soon. Tyler Technologies (TYL) has etched a flat base. The buy point is 113.74. Tyler is a good example of how new buy points can present themselves after a breakout. Tyler broke out with conviction over a 97.63 buy point in October.
Group peer Virtusa (VRTU) is also sculpting a flat base with a 42.59 entry.
Retail stocks were in the spotlight Thursday after November retail sales handily topped expectations before the open.

Discount retailer Ross Stores (ROST) is trading tightly after a recent breakout over a 77.13 cup-with-handle buy point. Zumiez (ZUMZ), meanwhile is finding support at its 10-week moving average for the first time after a cup-with-handle breakout in October over 33.15.

In the restaurant space, Buffalo Wild Wings (BWLD) is holding above a recent cup-with-handle buy point of 164.58. Technically, it's in buy range because it's less than 5% past the buy point, but it's been a low-volume breakout so far.Distribution and stalling days have been making their presence felt in the major averages in recent weeks, sparking a recent shift in outlook to "uptrend under pressure."Despite gains for the market Thursday, sellers were around again as a 1.6% intraday gain for the Nasdaq faded to 0.5% by the close.Still, this week's screen of leading stocks throughout IBD's 197 industry groups is home to plenty of actionable charts as well as stocks showing constructive price action post-breakout.Among media stocks, Time Warner (TWX) is working on a cup-with-handle base with a buy point of 85.54.In the enterprise software space, NetSuite's (N) cup-with-handle base shows a buy point of 111.08, but also a 42% correction on the left side. Stocks eased further in early-afternoon trade Friday, but the major indexes still held modest to moderate gains.The S&P 500 and Dow Jones industrial average each rose 0.4%, while the Nasdaq was up 0.3% . Volume continued to run higher than the same time Thursday on both exchanges.Construction equipment, design software and solar stocks were among the top gainers in the stock market today, while consumer electronics retailers, automakers and food stocks declined.Caterpillar (CAT) lifted the Machinery-Construction/Mining group by 3%, as the stock rose 4% to a two-month high in heavy trade. Stifel Nicolaus began covering the tractor maker with a buy rating and 122 price target, citing potential upside in margins.GameStop (GME) was largely responsible for the consumer electronics group's weakness, as it gapped down and sank 12% in massive trade, taking out both its 50-day and 200-day moving average lines. The video game retailer late Thursday reported Q3 profit of 57 cents a share ex items, down 2% from the prior year and 4 cents below views. Sales slipped 1% to $2.09 billion, vs. forecasts for $2.2 billion.Ross Stores (ROST) gapped up and soared 7% to an all-time high in huge volume. The stock is now extended 15% past a 77.13 buy point it initially cleared Oct. 3. The off-price retailer late Thursday reported Q3 profit of 93 cents a share, up 16% from last year and 6 cents over views. Revenue rose 8% to $2.6 billion, also topping. Maxim Group upgraded the stock to hold from sell.Among Leaderboard stocks, GoPro (GPRO) recouped 2% in above-average volume. The stock, which is shaping a new base, is 26% off its high. But it's still up 45% from a 50 buy point of an IPO base. The sports-selfie camera maker will present at upcoming conferences in London, New York and San Francisco on Dec. 3, Dec. 8 and Dec. 9, respectively.Follow Nancy Gondo on Twitter: @IBD_NGondo.
Stock futures were high and muscling higher ahead of Friday's open, as global markets responded to central bank news out of China and Europe.
Dow futures were 154 points above fair market value and rising. Nasdaq 100 futures were ahead a powerful 37.4 points. S&P 500 futures were also unusually high, up 18.9 points.

The stock market today faces no major economic reports. But premarket action showed U.S. investors responding vigorously to corporate earnings reports and tracking the international market response to central bank action taken Friday in China and strongly implied in Europe.
The People's Bank of China ratcheted up what has been a very reserved approach to fending off deflation, lowering key target interest rates for the first time since 2012.

European Central Bank head Mario Draghi told a European annual banking congress the eurozone economy's "excessively low" inflation was unacceptable and that the ECB was prepared to boost efforts to provide stimulus. The two central banks shifted posture following a raft of PMI data released Thursday showed growth in the Chinese and European economies flagging.
The PBOC news bumped the Shanghai composite up 1.4% Friday, giving it a fractional gain for the week. Hong Kong's Hang Seng added 0.4%, leaving it with a loss for the week of 2.6%.

European investors were more exuberant, sending Frankfurt's DAX and Paris' CAC-40 up 2.1% by midday. The indexes were up 4.8% and 2.5%, respectively, for the week. The FTSE 100 in London rose 1% and was tracking toward a 1.4% gain for the week.

In U.S. stocks, Splunk (SPLK) spiked 8% before the open. Shares had jumped in extended trade Thursday after the enterprise software provider reported a 2-cent per-share profit in the third quarter, a penny above views. Revenue growth also bested forecasts, and management gave stronger-than-expected guidance. The stock is up 59% since August as it climbs the right side of a deep, 11-month consolidation.

Ross Stores (ROST) stamped out a 6% premarket gain. The discount clothing chain reported last Thursday both its earnings and revenue easily topped analyst third-quarter consensus views. Operating margins expanded 55 basis points, the company said, due to lower cost of goods and a decline in selling and administrative expenses.
Ross ended Thursday at a new high, 8% above a flat-base buy point.

On the downside, Aruba Networks (ARUN) shed 8% ahead of the open. Its fiscal first-quarter revenue and earnings, reported late Thursday, grew more than expected. Operating margins expanded and the company reported widening its market share vs. major competitors. But management's revenue guidance raised questions with investors. The stock ended Thursday still holding 10-week support, building the right side of a two-month base.

The yen rose against the dollar after Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe officially disbanded the country's lower house of parliament and called an early election, scheduled for mid-December. Investors had anticipated the move, and Tokyo's Nikkei 225 responded with a 0.3% gain, ending the week effectively flat.

The dollar gained against the euro. Oil futures jumped 2%. Natural gas eased but held at recent, strong levels. Gold climbed almost 1%, holding just below $1,198 an ounce.Stock futures were high and muscling higher ahead of Friday's open, as global markets responded to central bank news out of China and Europe.Dow futures were 154 points above fair market value and rising. Retail and construction stocks got a lift Wednesday after a better-than-expected gain in private payrolls suggested the economy remains in good shape. Private employers added 241,000 jobs in December, according to payroll processor ADP. That beat forecasts for an increase of 235,000 jobs. The buoyant job figures suggested the world's biggest economy remains on track despite slowdowns in Europe, China…

The IBD 50's four-week winning streak came to an end Friday as the index of leading growth stocks lost 3% for the week. It was a tough week for the broad market, too, as the S&P 500 lost 3.5%. The IBD 50 generally has had a hard time keeping up with the S&P 500 in recent weeks, resulting in a…

The specialty retail sector is off to a promising start to the holiday shopping season, according to a new report from Sterne Agee, with names like Ulta Beauty (ULTA) and Ross Stores (ROST) leading the way.In a note released Monday morning, Sterne Agee analyst Ike Boruchow said the first two weeks of November "appear to show signs of hope for retailers, as checks/data points suggest a solid start to the month."Foot traffic has "improved meaningfully," he said, with "the best readings since late July." Meanwhile, promotional activity "has ticked down" although it still remains elevated overall."Though November saw an unseasonably warm start to the month with above-average temperatures, store traffic reversed just in time for the holiday season," Boruchow noted. "The reversal in trends is a welcome sight following a sluggish post-BTS (back-to-school) selling season, especially considering these were the strongest traffic readings since July."In terms of stocks favored by investors, Boruchow said the top names are dominated by "high-quality, defensive" retailers such as Ross and T.J. Maxx owner TJX (TJX) as well as beauty names like Ulta and Sally Beauty Holdings (SBH).Ulta, an IBD 50 stock, has a Composite Rating of 99. It is the highest rated stock in IBD's Retail-Specialty group, which ranks No. 19 of 197 industries tracked. Other leaders in the group include Michaels (MIK), with a Composite Rating of 94; and and Petsmart (PETM), with a Composite Rating of 89.Ross has a Composite Rating of 90. It belongs to IBD's Retail-Apparel/Shoes/Accessories group, which ranks No. 71. The top stock in the group is Foot Locker (FL), with a Composite Rating of 92. Foot Locker has earnings on Friday.

Entering the Foot Locker store in Times Square on Halloween morning, you knew you were in Nike country. Front and center, Nike's newest basketball shoe, the LeBron 12 HRT of a Lion, which hit stores the day before, was displayed under glass like a work of fine art. The shoe's debut coincided with LeBron James' first NBA regular-season game playing…

Shares of Foot Locker (FL) dropped nearly 5% in the stock market today after the giant athletic footwear retailer announced this morning that Ken Hicks will retire from his post as CEO on Dec. 1. But Sterne Agee analyst Sam Poser reiterated his buy rating on Foot Locker, an IBD 50 stock, citing confidence in Hicks' successor and the management…

This week's Your Weekly Review column is reflecting good market vibes since the Nasdaq composite followed through on Oct. 21. How so? For starters, it's nice to see the list expand back to more than 120 names only a week after the Oct. 21 follow-through. That's cheery. (Pages A5-A8 show the mini-charts of the first 120 in the list.) Second,…

A few Big Cap leaders remain near buy points, even though a market correction isn't an ideal time to buy. Union Pacific (UNP) ran into resistance on June 23, the same day it edged past a 103.06 flat-base buy point before closing below the entry. Over the next two weeks, it pulled back as much as 6%, not quite enough…

Two tools are useful when looking for signs of institutional buying. The up-down volume ratio and IBD's proprietary Accumulation/Distribution Rating are the two gauges. The up-down volume ratio divides total volume on up days in the past 50 days by total volume on down days. A ratio greater than 1.0 points to positive demand for the stock. The Accumulation/Distribution Rating…

Retailers posted solid sales gains in November that handily beat views Thursday as early deals combined with low gas prices prompted shoppers to loosen their purse strings a bit and spend more freely. Sales at stores open at least a year rose 5% vs. a year earlier, according to Ken Perkins, president of Retail Metrics. That compares with a 4%…

A weak market has resulted in plenty of damage to leading growth stocks, but several institutional-quality names — and some lesser-known ones — have weathered the market storm quite well. Keurig Green Mountain (GMCR) is trading tightly near highs after an August breakout over 128.60. It's a tad extended now, but its 10-week moving average around 132 could be a…

Burlington Stores (BURL) reported a narrowed per-share loss and increased revenue in the second quarter that surpassed Wall Street expectations, prompting the company to raise its full-year guidance. The discount retailer, which went public in October 2013, lost 1 cent in Q2. But that beat a Thomson Reuters analyst poll for an 8-cent loss, and improved from a 19-cent loss…
Stock futures shed Thursday's premarket gains and reversed to moderate losses after mixed reports on unemployment claims and Q3 GDP growth.

Dow futures dropped 57.2 points below fair market value, down from a 44-point advance an hour earlier. Nasdaq 100 futures shed an 18-point gain and dropped 20.7 points. S&P 500 futures also reversed, trading down 6.7 points.

The stock market today received a boost from the Federal Reserve Wednesday that left the Nasdaq up 1.3% so far this week and the S&P 500 showing a 0.7% gain. Both indexes are working on what would be a fifth straight weekly advance.

More important for growth investors, small caps are having a strong week. The Russell 2000 surged 2.9% Wednesday — it's strongest session since Dec. 17, 2014. That lifted the small cap gauge clear of its 50-day moving average and put it ahead 1.1% for the week. Even so, the index remains well below its next test of resistance at its 200-day line.
The IBD 50 Index popped 1.6% on Wednesday and is easily outpacing the market with a 3.6% gain for the week.

A big day of economic news was off to a mixed start, with a preliminary estimate from the Commerce Department putting Q3 GDP growth at 1.5%, less than half of the 3.9% jump in Q2 and just below forecasts for a 1.7% increase. Price inflation also softened, with the GDP price index rising 1.2%, down from 2.1% in Q2 and a shade below views for a 1.4% advance.

Unemployment claims inched fractionally higher, to 260,000, in the week ended Oct. 24, the Labor Department reported. That was better than the uptick to 265,000 claims forecast by economists. The prior week's tally was 259,000 claims. The four-week moving average dipped to 259,250, its sixth straight decline.

Atlanta Federal Reserve Bank President Dennis Lockhart is scheduled to speak in Washington, D.C., at 9:10 a.m. ET. The National Association of Realtors reports September pending home sales data at 10 a.m.

Big oil companies got the earnings ball rolling, with Royal Dutch Shell (RDSA), Total (TOT) and ConocoPhillips (COP) all down 2% after reporting results. Oil prices backed off 1%, with West Texas Intermediate at $45.51 a barrel after surging more than 6% Wednesday.

Drug maker Pfizer (PFE) climbed 3% and Allergan (AGN) soared 11% on news reports that the two companies are exploring a possible merger. The Wall Street Journal quoted unnamed sources saying the talks were in early stages and details were unclear. Pfizer ended Wednesday up 4% for the week and less than 2% above a 34.79 buy point in a cup-with-handle base.

Among the premarket session's wilder moves, identity security firm Lifelock (LOCK) soared 40% on healthy Q3 results reported late Wednesday, along with news that it had settled a Federal Trade Commission lawsuit. Digital video camera maker GoPro (GPRO) dived 18% on weaker-than-forecast Q3 sales and earnings, also reported after Wednesday's close.

Among leading stocks, O'Reilly Automotive (ORLY) jumped 3%, Tesoro (TSO) rose 2% and Ellie Mae (ELLI) was flat after their Q3 reports. O'Reilly ended Wednesday's session in buy range, less than 2% above a 258.25 buy point. Tesoro was 3% below a 105.64 buy point in a cup-with-handle base.

NXP Semiconductor (NXPI) dived 13%. The Netherlands-based chip maker reported Q3 earnings up a stronger-than-expected 16%, but revenue rose less than 1% — weaker than estimates. Management expanded its stock buyback initiative to 20 million shares. NXP finished Wednesday just below its 10-week moving average, and has been working to climb the right side of a four-month consolidation.
Cavium (CAVM) took an 11% hit after reporting in-line Q3 earnings and revenue late Wednesday. The chip maker has been chopping out an uneven consolidation, and fighting to hold support, since June.

Stocks opened mostly lower but quickly turned and crept into positive territory early Friday.

The Dow Jones industrial average and the Nasdaq edged up 0.1% each. The S&P 500 posted a fractional gain. Small caps lagged, with the Russell 2000 still down 0.4%. Volume was tracking lower across the board.

The stock market today appeared to turn higher in response to opening comments from Fed chief Janet Yellen, who was speaking to a group of global finance and economic leaders in Jackson Hole, Wyo. Yellen said the Fed was carefully weighing labor market slack relative to the need for and timing of any potential increase in the Fed's target interest rate. She also said recent unemployment data appeared to overstate the economy's progress.

In stocks, Dynegy (DYN) spiked 12% after announcing it would pay $6.25 billion for a portfolio of generation assets from Duke Energy (DUK) and Energy Capital Partners. The deal would nearly double the generation capacity of the electrical utility, which emerged from bankruptcy protection in 2012. The jump left Dynegy shares below the left-side high in a 31% deep consolidation begun in June. Duke Energy shares rose a fraction.

Keurig Green Mountain (GMCR) bolted 8% higher after the progenitor of K-cup coffee announced a multi-year deal with Kraft Foods (KRFT). The multiyear deal aims to make Kraft brands including Maxwell House, Gevalia and Yuban coffee available in "portion packs" compatible with Keurig consumer and commercial brewing systems. The gain lifted shares to just below a 128.60 buy point in an eight week flat base. Kraft shares rose a fraction.

Ross Stores (ROST) snapped up 7% in heavy trade. The discount retailer late Thursday reported Q2 earnings that were comfortably above analyst forecasts. Revenue met expectations. Q3 earnings guidance also met consensus views, while management gave Q4 guidance below consensus. Gross margins increased sharply, and the company reported a 45-basis-point decrease in selling, general and administrative expenses. The move hoisted shares back above 10-week support as the stock attempts to climb the right side of a nine-month consolidation.

On the IBD 50 list, GasLog (GLOG) dragged down 2%, putting it down 7% so far for the week. The stock triggered the 8% sell rule after a June breakout attempt failed, and after diving below support at its 10-week moving average in heavy trade July 31.

Ambarella (AMBA) slipped 2% but remains up 4% so far in a third straight weekly gain. The stock is working at recovering from a test of 10-week support after a brief breakout attempt failed in early July.Stocks opened mostly lower but quickly turned and crept into positive territory early Friday.The Dow Jones industrial average and the Nasdaq edged up 0.1% each. Q3 earnings guidance also met consensus views, while management gave Q4 guidance below consensus. Gross margins increased sharply, and the company reported a 45-basis-point decrease in selling, general and administrative expenses. The move hoisted shares back above 10-week support as the stock attempts to climb the right side of a nine-month consolidation.On the IBD 50 list, GasLog (GLOG) dragged down 2%, putting it down 7% so far for the week. The stock triggered the 8% sell rule after a June breakout attempt failed, and after diving below support at its 10-week moving average in heavy trade July 31.Ambarella (AMBA) slipped 2% but remains up 4% so far in a third straight weekly gain. The stock is working at recovering from a test of 10-week support after a brief breakout attempt failed in early July.

Retailers Ross Stores (ROST) and Fresh Market (TFM) were active in extended trading after reporting quarterly results. Ross missed on sales, while Fresh Market disappointed on top and bottom lines. Shares of Fresh Market slumped 14% after hours, while Ross dropped 6%.
In the regular session, stocks staged a big comeback from recent losses Thursday in the face of mixed economic data and news of Janet Yellen moving closer to becoming the next Federal Reserve chair.

The Nasdaq rallied 1.2% and the S&P 500 rose 0.8%. Both scored their first gains of the weak. Meanwhile, the Dow Jones industrial average climbed 0.7%. According to preliminary data, volume was mixed in the stock market today. Nasdaq trade dipped, but NYSE volume edged higher.

In leading stocks, Green Mountain Coffee Roasters (GMCR) gapped up and surged 14% after reporting late fiscal fourth-quarter sales and earnings that easily beat views late Wednesday. Earnings per share popped 39% and sales rose 11%. The company also added $1 billion to its stock buyback and announced a special dividend of a $1 a share and declared a regular dividend of 25 cents a share. Green Mountain closed back above its 50-day and 200-day moving averages.

Nu Skin Enterprises (NUS) gapped up and rallied 4% to an all-time high after giving bullish guidance. Early Thursday, the marketer of beauty and nutritional products guided 2014 sales at $3.9 billion to $4 billion. It pegged earnings at $7.25 to $7.50 a share. Both were well above current views. The lift puts the IBD 50 stock more than 30% past a 90.10 buy point from a flat base cleared in September.
Foot Locker (FL), Hibbett Sports (HIBB) and PetSmart (PETM) are a few notable companies reporting earnings Friday.

Stock futures stepped off firm gains ahead of Thursday's open as the market looked to wrap up its holiday-shortened week.Dow futures were 60.1 points above fair market value. Nasdaq 100 futures jumped 18.8 points. S&P 500 futures were ahead 8.8 points and rising. Small caps had also improved, with Russell 2000 futures turning early losses into a 1.3-point gain.The payroll report is the top piece of U.S. economic news for the stock market today, but eyes remain sharply focused on Greece, where a referendum vote on Sunday could determine whether the country will remain part of or exit the eurozone. Greece's prime minister and finance minister have made clear they are firmly in favor of a "no" vote, which would refuse the so-called austerity measures demanded by eurozone creditors in exchange for continued bailout support. Europe's top stock indexes in Frankfurt and Paris were effectively flat near midsession, while London's FTSE 100 edged up 0.4%.U.S. nonfarm payrolls expanded by 223,000 in May, the Labor Department reported. That was a sharp downtick from April's downwardly revised total of 254,000 new jobs, and below expectations for 230,000 new hires. Private employers accounted for all the additions, with the labor force participation rate down 30 basis points to 62.6% and the unemployment rate dipping to 5.3%, from 5.5% in April and below forecasts for 5.4%. Average hourly earnings were flat, below expectations for a 0.2% gain.Initial jobless claims rose to 281,000 for the week ended June 27, a 3.6% increase over the prior week. Consensus forecasts called for a slight decrease to 270,000. The four-week moving average increased to 272,750, its first increase in three weeks.May factory orders data are due from the Commerce Department at 10 a.m. ET.Early stock action showed online international money transfer service Xoom (XOOM) vaulting 23% in premarket trade. EBay (EBAY) subsidiary PayPal announced after Wednesday's close it would acquire the San Francisco-based startup for approximately $890 million. EBay announced last week it would complete its spinoff of PayPal as a separately traded entity on July 17. EBay shares rose 1%.Tesla Motors (TSLA) jumped 4% ahead of the open. The Palo Alto, Calif.-based car and battery maker reported its sales of Model S sedans rose 52% in the second quarter vs. the year-ago period. The result topped the company's own best-case estimate of 11,000 vehicles by about 500 units. Tesla shares ended Wednesday up 48% from a March low, in a possible nine-month cup base.IBD 50 stock Centene (CNC) rose 2% after agreeing to buy Health Net (HNT) in a cash and stock transaction valued at $6.8 billion. Centene said the deal included $500 million in debt and would boost the company's earnings by 20% in the first year. Centene is extended, recovered to new highs after a high-volume stab through its 10-week line flashed a sell signal in April. Health Net shares spiked 15% before Thursday's open.Overseas, China's mainland markets took another steep step down. The Shanghai Composite shed 3.5% Friday for a 6.6% loss for the week. Hong Kong's Hang Seng edged up 0.1%, down 1.4% for the week. In Japan, Tokyo's Nikkei 225 gained 1% and took a weekly loss of 0.1% through Thursday.The dollar was mixed, down vs. the euro, up against the yen. In commodities, oil rose a fraction, with U.S. West Texas Intermediate just above $57 a barrel and down almost 5% vs. last Friday's settle price. Gold dipped to near $1,161 an ounce Friday, down a bit more than 1% for the week. Wheat, which has had a volatile week, was slightly higher and trading up nearly 4% for the week at $5.84 a bushel.

Wealth-Making Patterns: Second In A Series
Claude Monet was awesome. But go to La Musee Marmottan Monet in Paris (if you like Monet) and what will you see?

Some viewers walk right up and put their face right into the painting, as if they want to smell it. They are awed by the minutest details of brush stroke and texture. But they miss the fuller view of the brilliant painting.
Stock charts can be the same way. It takes some stepping back to catch long patterns that may otherwise go undetected.
That's how many long cup or saucer bases appear. Some of these cups can run from three to 12 months. That's where weekly charts come in handy.
Might you lose that day-to-day scrutiny that appears in the daily charts? Certainly, but you needn't abandon them. Use daily charts in conjunction with weekly charts.
Look at discount retailer Ross Stores' (ROST) saucer that it formed from October 2009 through early March 2010 1. It ran just 16% deep.
This is the sort of pattern that might not have been so obvious if you were just flipping through daily charts. A look at the weekly chart would have left you no doubt this was a pattern to study.

Length doesn't necessarily translate to a solid base unless the pattern has the proper characteristics. A good long base will have tight price movements, up weeks in heavy volume — just like a good short base.
Ross Stores' base was tight, but did suffer from one week of intense volume 2.
The stock broke out and advanced more than 15% until it started correcting again. Ross formed another long, constructive base 3. That breakout led to a long climb.
Ross Stores shows a second reason to scour the weekly charts: They can tell you if a stock has gone from volatile to tight action, or vice versa.
For example, before Ross formed its two saucer bases, it came out of a base with a severe 48% decline.

On the weekly chart, you'd have seen the 21-week base that ran just 16% deep. Where did all this tighter action come from? From funds that had discovered Ross Stores. They supported it on any pullback.Wealth-Making Patterns: Second In A SeriesClaude Monet was awesome. The country's best-performing funds of the past three months have been stoking their portfolios with big-cap biotech stocks, such as Alexion Pharmaceuticals (ALXN), Amgen (AMGN), Biogen Idec (BIIB) and Regeneron Pharmaceuticals (REGN).

As of Thursday, the IBD Medical Biomed/Biotech group was ranked No. 1 among 197 sectors. The group has been hovering among the top four spots for most of this year. The sector was up 16% this year through July.
Amgen, Gilead Sciences (GILD), Alexion and Onyx Pharmaceuticals (ONXX) each has notched new 52-week highs in recent weeks.
Managers of leading funds also have been shopping retail stocks, including Ross Stores (ROST), TJX Cos. (TJX), Foot Locker (FL), GNC Holdings (GNC) and Francesca's Holdings (FRAN).
Fast-food chains Papa John's International (PZZA) and AFC Enterprises (AFCE), which runs Popeyes Chicken, have been stellar performers.
Top funds have also been snatching up cable and satellite operators Comcast (CMCSA) and Time Warner (TWC).
Ross Stores
IBD found five top-notch funds adding Ross Stores, investing an estimated $1.90 million. The $249 million Hennessy Cornerstone Growth Fund added shares as of its latest reporting period.
The lousy economy is a boon for discount retailers such as Ross Stores. The Pleasanton, Calif.-based firm runs 1,037 Ross Dress For Less stores and 88 dd's Discounts stores in the U.S.
Ross' same-store sales for July jumped 7% to $709 million, up from $635 million a year earlier.
It raised second-quarter earnings guidance to a range between 80 and 81 cents, up from 77 to 78 cents as previously expected.
The stock has more than doubled from 33.50 during last summer's sell-off in August to a 52-week high of 70 in mid-July. It's pulled back to 66, just 5% off its high.
Sell Side
The best-performing funds have been taking profits in utility issues, including FirstEnergy (FE), Atmos Energy (ATO) and PG&E (PCG) in their latest reporting periods.

TJX and Ross Stores are expected to report rising earnings growth when the discounters announce quarterly results this week, after a disappointing holiday quarter.

TJX (TJX), the operator of T.J. Maxx and Home Goods stores, is slated to report first-quarter results Tuesday. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expect the discounter to report an 8% jump in earnings to 67 cents per share. Last quarter, earnings growth declined. Revenue is expected to rise 6.7% to $6.6 billion.
"With the winter weather, we saw a lot of store closures," John Kernan, director at the Cowen research firm, told IBD. "There wasn't much of a fashion trend going on."
Kernan is expecting TJX to talk more about its Home Goods expansion and its expansion of T.J. Maxx stores in Europe.

TJX has an EPS rank of 84. IBD's EPS Rating measures both recent quarter and longer-term earnings growth rates. Stocks with EPS Ratings of 84 have outperformed 84% of all publicly traded companies in earnings.
In April, TJX raised its quarterly dividend 21% to 17.5 cents per share.

Ross Stores (ROST) is scheduled to report results Thursday. Analysts are expecting the retailer to report a 8.4% rise in EP to $1.16. In Q4, Ross reported a 5% drop in earnings growth. Revenue is seen climbing 6% to $2.69 billion. In Q4, revenue dipped 1%, its first decline in more than 10 years.
Discounters weren't the only retailers to struggle during the holiday quarter as customers kept their wallets closed when it came to apparel and home goods.
But sales have been picking up broadly in April on warmer weather and improved economic data.
Earlier this month, Ross Chief Merchandising Officer Barbara Rentler was tapped to be CEO, succeeding Michael Balmuth, who will be stepping down on June 1.

It's important to know the cup-without-handle base and cup-with-handle base, two classic stock chart patterns.Chartists also need to make sure they're familiar with a related structure, which IBD has dubbed the saucer base.As you might guess, the saucer is a shallower pattern than the cup. You might see a correction of about 12% to 20%, while a typical cup can run as deep as 35%.Sometimes a stock will tack on a handle to its saucer base. Other times it's in a hurry, and the stock breaks out to new highs without sketching a handle.What about length? A proper saucer takes at least seven weeks to develop. You also could have saucers that are a year long or more.For a good example of a saucer base, check out Ross Stores ' (ROST) action in 2010.The Pleasanton, Calif.-based discount clothing and home goods retailer began to etch the saucer in mid-June 2010, as it slid toward its 10-week line. (1)You could also view the saucer as starting in late April, and that would give roughly the same left-side high for the pattern.Ross established a bottom for this saucer in August 2010, and then it proceeded to build the base's right side. The pattern featured a correction of 16% — or 17%, if you viewed the pattern as starting in late April.Ross appeared to add a handle to its saucer in late September and early October.  (2) However, volume wasn't strong as the stock moved past that handle pattern. A better interpretation is just to view Ross' consolidation as a simple saucer.In mid-to-late October, the stock edged past a 56.72 handle buy point and out of that saucer (the weekly chart reflects a 2-for-1 split in December 2011). In the Nov. 1 IBD, Ross held an 88 Composite Rating, a 97 EPS, 74 RS and an A grade for SMR.Then in the week ended Nov. 5, big volume kicked in, and Ross really charged ahead. (3)Sometimes volume can kick in a bit late with a breakout, but the move still works out.Note this breakout occurred not long after the Sept. 1, 2010, follow-through day that signaled a fresh market uptrend. That means if you bought the stock, you benefited from a positive general environment.Ross rose 144%, building new bases along the way, until it peaked in August 2012.

Stocks added to early gains, although volume quieted near midday Thursday.

The Nasdaq kept its lead, up 0.9%. The S&P 500 and the Dow Jones industrial average each climbed 0.6%. Volume slipped from early levels and turned mixed, up 1% on the Nasdaq and a fraction lower on the NYSE, vs. trade at the same time Wednesday.

The stock market today opened to positive economic news: a decrease in weekly jobless claims and inflation numbers in line with forecasts. Philadelphia region manufacturing slowed much more than expected, but investors seemed more keen on individual company reports and on technical factors.

In addition, the Senate Banking Committee cleared Janet Yellen's nomination to the chairman's post at the Federal Reserve. The approval clears the way for a final confirmation vote before the full Senate. Yellen has generally been viewed as a positive for the market, suggesting only gradual change in the Fed's accommodative monetary policy.

Green Mountain Coffee Roasters (GMCR) knocked the cover off the ball, up 18% in massive trade after a strong fiscal fourth quarter. The gain yanked shares back above the stock's converged 10- and 40-week moving averages, pushing toward a second weekly advance off the bottom of a three-month, 37% correction.
Leading stocks continued to build on their broad, early advance.
Nu Skin Enterprises (NUS) defended its 6% gain, edging to a new high in very strong trade.
Ambarella (AMBA) climbed 5% in mild trade. The maker of chips used largely in sports and security cameras is hanging just below Monday's high, in its second rebound from 10-week support.

Yandex (YNDX) popped 4% in strong trade, chinning up to its 50-day moving average. The Netherlands-based provider of search engine services to Russia's Internet is five weeks into a flat consolidation with 10-week support.

In good times or bad, shoppers are looking for value. For clothing and home goods, consumers often have turned to Ross Stores (ROST).
The Pleasanton, Calif.-based retailer sells apparel, shoes, cookware and other household goods at deep discounts.
Ross is able to offer lower prices because it buys excess inventories from department stores.

On Thursday, Ross delivered a round of good news. First, it reported a 3% rise in its January same-store sales. That was well ahead of the 0.5% increase expected by analysts polled by Thomson Reuters.

Second, citing strong January sales, the company raised its fiscal Q4 profit forecast to $1.36 or $1.37 a share from $1.16 a share. That would mark an increase of 17% or 18% from the year-ago level. Analysts' EPS estimates are $1.34.

Its profit for fiscal 2010 ended in January is now expected at $4.62 or $4.63 a share vs. views for $4.60. The company will report results on March 17. For its fiscal 2011, the retailer sees earnings coming in between $4.90 and $5.10 a share vs. analysts' estimates for $5.02. Ross' EPS growth had slowed the past three quarters, from 61% to 30% to 21%.

Ross also boosted its quarterly dividend by 38% to 22 cents a share. On an annualized basis, that works out to a rate of 88 cents a share for a yield of 1.3%. The new dividend will be paid on March 31 to shareholders of record as of Feb. 18.
The company has lifted its payout each year since it began paying cash dividends in 1994.

Additionally, Ross announced that its board of directors approved a new two-year, $900 million share buyback program. The new buyback replaces what's left from a prior $750 million repurchase program set in January 2010.

Ross shares hit a record high Friday. The stock recently broke out of a flat base. It gapped up from the 50-day line on Thursday's news.In good times or bad, shoppers are looking for value.
